course.subject: ENVR
course.name: Science, Environment and Society - From Big Bang to Big Data
course.description: A scientific narrative of the evolution of the universe from the Big Bang all the way to the present (also known as Big History) will be introduced in this course. The course outlines how scientific methods can be used to understand the evolution of the physical, biological and social environment around us. It highlights the transdisciplinary nature of scientific knowledge, the importance of collaboration and self-critical claim testing, the accumulation of knowledge, the acceleration of technology all the way to Big Data and AI, and finally the social and environmental challenges posed by these changes. Climate change will be used as a detailed example of a complex environment and sustainability challenges in the 21st century.  Students will be guided to appreciate how collaborations and system-thinking with integration and sharing of concepts across disciplines are required for addressing these challenges.

reviews.author: yclee
reviews.title: Sleepy & a lot of stuff to remember
reviews.comment_content:
Tbh this course covers stuff from the Big Bang to the recent days, so the content is really heavy.  

Here is part of the topics included in this year's lecture:
- Geophysics
- Climate change basics
- Life, biological process
- Monkeys, Sapiens & Cognitive Revolution
- Agriculture Revolution
- Unification of humankind
- Scientific Revolution
- Sustainability challenges
- Climate Change
reviews.comment_teaching: He is super passionate in teaching about Big History and can always talk a lot about them.  So it is quite common for him to stay in 1 ppt slide and talk for 30 minutes.  However, sometimes it is hard to catch the main points of his explanation and what to jot down.  Also, sometimes his powerpoints are too wordy so...
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading of this course is relatively not transparent.  We only knew the grade for 2 of our essays and the mid-term.  In my opinion, he is quite lenient in grading the works.

Just for reference:
Mid-term: 85%
Essay 1: 7.5/10
Essay 2: 7.5/10
Final grade: A+...><
reviews.comment_workload:
- Class quizzes through iPRS (15%)
- Individual 3 short essays (No word limit) (3*10%)
- 1 Mid-term (TF / MCs) (30%)
- Group-based poster (15%) & Video (10%)

This year, the project was due during the study break period and the topic of the project was given to us near the study break, so actually the deadline was quite tight...

reviews.author: JY_XueBa_Not
reviews.title: Abstract content , Sleepy lecture
reviews.comment_content:
The content varies from year to year, therefore the following topic is only for reference.

The spring course revolves around 8 major thresholds:
1) The Big Bang
2) Stars Light Up
3) New Chemical elements
4) Earth and The Solar System
5) Life on Earth
6) Collective learning
7) Agriculture
8) The Modern Revolution

Simply looking at the titles it is really confusing. The major focus on this big history course is the comparison of timescales, major events and the significance of human. It allow us to rethink our power and what we should do in the present to maintain sustainable development.

The topic on collective learning feels like social science lectures, he placed much focus on the human & agriculture part.
All in all, the contents are really abstract but it is fairly easy to memorise through lectures and videos
reviews.comment_teaching:
Alexis loves to talk, he talks frequently during lectures. Engagement with class is low and he will play videos occasionally. The annoying part is in the lecture is that there will be PRS quizzes (12 times during the entire term) randomly so you have little chance to skip lessons.
In the middle of the term you will join in 2 class forums where you discuss with groups of 4 on projects and write two short essays submitted 2 weeks after the forum.
One time the prof. hint the next lesson will have no quiz. That 9am lecture ended up with less than 15 students showing up. (Class size is 96)
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is .... meh
It mainly depends on the TA. which is this term is an absolute asshole.

The grading consist of few parts including PRS, Attendance (2x forums), Project , 2x short essays, 1 long essay and Mid Term Exam

Typical mean grade is B-
I score
MT: 86/100 (Mean:75)
Project: 5/10 (Poster) and 7/10 (Video)
Short essay: 3/5 and 3.5/5
Long essay: 18/20
PRS: Idk

Final Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
There are quite a lot of things to do but its manageable. Especially there is no final exam , you don't have to worry about studying during final week. The midterm consist of MC and T/F questions, most of them comes from PRS questions, therefore must attend lessons!!!
The group project is the bias one as the score depends on certain rules on designing it. This limited the poster creativity. I even argue with the TA for remarking, but that asshole lack a sense of art appreciation and it is a waste of time to talk to him.
The asshole TA is Wai xxx Wong Aiden

Not heavy if you got good teammates (arrange by the professor).
Most workload lies on projects. Your group needs to design a poster and video that explain your ideas on the poster.

The one-page summary is easy, you just need to consolidate your group's idea.
Read ppt is enough for iPRS. You can search online or ppt during as it is open book.

reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is heavy.

Iprs is difficult and it is required time to search and find the answers in ppt. Friends or group mates are very important.

He did not state clearly about the assignment requirements and just said that the past students wrote around 10-15 pages without any samples so it is very difficult to write a long essay.

Midterm is open-booked and fair. We can open book and search the answers, which is basically stated on ppt. But the time is quite limited.

Group project is fair. Luckily, I met the hardworking group mates and the division of labour is clear.

However, the title or content of group project and the second assignment are too similar, which may be hard to distinguish and write some different things to get a high mark.

reviews.author: CCKK
reviews.title: Good grade but boring course
reviews.comment_content:
Climate change
Sustainability
The Big History

The course content was more or less like a "deeper" version of a general sense, giving worldwide examples and data.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would say the lectures were quite boring...

Alexis would give a really detailed PPT with tons of words and play video clips in the class. Seldom interaction with students.
Online lecture videos were also available. And actually watching videos were more efficient as you can speed it up and save time.

Some of the time he would talk about his own opinion regarding some environmental issues, which were not related to the course but trying to enhance students' awareness.
reviews.comment_grading:
IPRS quiz: 7 quizzes in total and count the best 5, each one accounts for 4%

Essay 1 (20%) : 16/20
Essay 2 (20%): IDK

Midterm:71

Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
IPRS was tricky and the answer can be anywhere inside the 80-paged PowerPoint. So you better sit with a group of your classmates so that everyone can search at the same time and share the answer (he allows discussion).

Two essays (with two posters) were easy to manage cause you just expressed your opinion with evidence to support. And the professor gave plenty of time and would postpone the deadlines if needed.

Midterm covered a lot of IPRS questions.

reviews.title: good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Climate change (IPCC, causes and effects,Vulnerability, risk and adaptation, migration)

Sustainability (Sustainability challenges, Local Government Efforts, Will society Collapse - Jared Dimond )

Big history (the whole history of how human evolute and develop civilisation including bigbang, solar system, sapiens, agriculture, scientific revolution)

The climate change part is easy to understand as it's just common sense. Sustainability issues are also okay as it relates the effect of climate change into different aspects like economy and society. He introduced "Collapse" from Jared Diamond, mainly about why society would collapse and it's easy to get too.

Lastly, the big history part. I think this part is the most interesting part because we can know how human develop into the current state through collective learning, social systems, interests and empire and the importance of money.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He speaks very slowly, when I watch the lecture videos, I speed it up to 2x. He emphasised a lot this course isn't about teaching you climate change or anything fancy as they can be found on the Internet easily, but there's something he wants us to take is the willingness to change and realise that we can still do a lot for our planets and humans.

However, his lectures are quite boring and many people fall asleep.
